utterances: I took a bunch.
For Bobbi, nostalgia and reflection ensued.
I'm just very grateful to be a very small part of Woodstock.
There's a lot of sadness, viciousness and selfishness in today's world.
And there was none of that at Woodstock.
When you talk about it, it doesn't feel like it's 50 years ago.
I think that's a fair assessment.
You can.
I mean, on the one hand, you have Kristen Gillibrand who was appointed to her seat.
She was regarded as an opportunity for Republicans to pick up a rare Senate seat in a blue state.
And what was amazing was that it was very hard for Republicans to find somebody to go up against her.
A lot of a big names considered it and bowed out.
And finally, there was kind of a free for all contests between a couple of Republican candidates.
And lo and behold, on primary day, Joe DioGuardi came out ahead.
And it wasnt just close, he was well ahead.
And so he seemed to be picking up some of that energy from the Tea Party movement.
He has the support of the conservative party in New York State.
He also has the support of a new party called the Taxpayers Party, which of course is the same party that the candidate for governor, Carl Paladino, has started for his own campaign.
So you see a bit of Tea Party energy in this race.
Now, both DioGuardi and the incumbent, Kirsten Gillibrand, are running very much as outsiders.
Here are a couple of clips from some of their commercials.
First, Gillibrand.
(Soundbite of a political ad)
I haven't been in Washington long but I've been there long enough to know that things are broken.
Thats why I've made transparency and accountability a top priority.
And, of course, before she was in the Senate, she was in the House of Representatives, as was Joe DioGuardi at one time.
But in one of his commercials, he says if you're looking accountability he's your man.
He's an accountant.
(Soundbite of a political ad)
Im a certified public accountant running for the U.S.
Senate, to get spending under control and to stop this credit card madness thats costing us jobs and the American dream.
Im Joe DioGuardi and I approve this message.
So both candidates want to come to Washington to clean up the mess here.
Well, it's fascinating that fiscal issues have kind of taken the fore in this race and many others across the country.
Social issues are not really in the forefront here; same-sex marriage is not a big issue, abortion is not a big issue.
It's about spending.
Now, onto the governor's race.
Democrat David Paterson, the incumbent who succeeded the disgraced Eliot Spitzer, is not running for election.
So it's Democrat Andrew Cuomo, the state attorney general, against Republican Carl Paladino.
That's correct.
So in one corner, you have a Democrat who is as well-known as any Democrat in the country, and this is Andrew Cuomo.
And in the other corner, you have a candidate who, I would assume that most New Yorkers had never heard of until he won his party's primary.
And again, it wasnt just a little bit.
He crushed the former Congressman Rick Lazio in the Republican primary.
And so, what we have here is a candidate who was behind but who has a lot of energy - Carl Paladino.

And a candidate, Andrew Cuomo, who was long regarded as the inevitable next governor, who now has to wonder if he can really counterattack against a guy with some energy and some grassroots support on the right.
And again, it's all about spending and state finances?
Thats correct.

And in fact, Andrew Cuomo is running mostly on a platform of getting the famously dysfunctional state capital in New York, Albany, under control - both in terms of its spending, which keep growing beyond inflation almost every year in the past decade, and in terms of the ethics and dysfunction of the process there.
Whats interesting is that Andrew Cuomo is both kind of running as a reform candidate as an outsider, but of course, he is the consummate insider.
He is a member of a political dynasty in New York.
And so, all of a sudden he faces a contender who's sort of a more genuine or true outsider in the conventional sense, Carl P.
Paladino, who is a Buffalo business who was a protest candidate a few weeks ago, and then suddenly a major party's candidate for governor.
And Rick Lazio, who is the object of that protest and who lost in the primary, today got completely out of the race by giving up the spot on the conservative party ballot line.
Yes.
And that was actually hugely important for Carl Paladino because not since the 1970s has a Republican candidate for statewide office won, without having the conservative line in New York State.
It's hugely important for Republicans.
There was a question for a while as to whether Rick Lazio would stay in the race as the conservative candidate.
He decided to back out and there will be some kind of a legal maneuver where he'll be taken off the ballot.
And presumably, Paladino will be placed on the ballot.
He'll then have both the conservative line and the GOP line.
Well, Nicholas Confessore, thanks a lot for talking with us.
My pleasure.
Nicholas Confessore, political reporter of The New York Times, spoke to us from New York City.
This past week, the Federal Trade Commission decided to enter into a settlement with Mark Zuckerberg, head of Facebook, which I'll say here is an NPR sponsor.
The FTC entered into that settlement without interviewing Zuckerberg first.
And as NPR's Aarti Shahani reports, the government may have missed its chance to find out more about Facebook's practices.
The year was 2014.
Mark Zuckerberg was onstage at F8, Facebook's annual conference, with a promise to users.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
The thing is we don't ever want anyone to be surprised about how they're sharing on Facebook.
I mean, that's not good for anyone.
His company had gotten caught taking the personal data of Facebook users and, without consent, handing it off to outsiders, third-party app developers.
So this was his promise.
(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING)
Butterfield says depending on the price of sugar, it could cost as a little as a dollar a gallon to make ethanol.
The MicroFueler can also run on leftover alcohol like beer, which can be turned into ethanol, and that would cost just 10 to 25 cents a gallon.
But critics question whether the alternative fuels actually save consumers' money.
Experts say the fuels might damage your car, and there are legal issues as well.
One needs a federal permit to brew ethanol at home, and the EPA says it's illegal to run cars on 100-percent ethanol or 100-percent vegetable oil.
In fact, a company that modifies vehicles to run on vegetable oil, faces a maximum fine of 32,500 dollars per violation.
The maximum fine for an individual who does so is 2,750 dollars.
State laws vary.
(Soundbite of liquid being poured)
In Maryland where James Baronschmidt mixes his fuel, drivers using vegetable oil face a fine if they don't register with the state and fail to file monthly payments.
He says he'll register, but he says he hopes an increasing outcry from people who are taking their fuel production into their own hands goads the government into changing its standards.
Sometimes, I mean, that's what you really need to bring about change.
Then there'd be more people like Baronschmidt, who basically don't go to gas stations at all, except to fill up their tires.
Allison Keyes, NPR News Washington.
The annual G8 or Group of Eight Nations Summit begins today in Northern Japan.
On the agenda - issues like aid to Africa, the environment, and the world economy.
But at the end of the three-day meeting, will anything truly be accomplished?
We're joined now by Fred Bergsten.
He's the director of the Peterson Institute for International Economics.
Thanks for joining us, and let's start off by talking about traditionally speaking, what usually comes out of the G8 Summit?
The G8 usually has a series of economic management issues that they address.
They talk about global trade negotiations, like in the World Trade Organization.
They talk about the economic outwork and whether there are policy changes they can address to help that.

They increasingly in recent years talk about foreign assistance to Africa and other poor parts of the world in an effort to improve living standards and reduce poverty in the most distressed parts of the global economy.
In addition, they inevitably take up the political hot topic of the day.
This year, things are fairly quiet on that front, so I don't see anything quite of that nature coming in into this meeting in Japan.
Therefore, they may in fact wind up focusing more on the economic topics.
As you mentioned, there's a whole lot of talk, but is there ever any real action?
Can you look back and say OK, here are some real accomplishments that have come out of the G8 Summit?
The G8 Summit have waxed and waned over the years.

Back when they got going in the 1970s, they took very important steps to deal with the oil shocks of that period, the global energy crisis, the global inflation that had resulted after the original oil crisis.
In the 1980s, they took some very important steps to deal with the big trade imbalances and protections problems.
Over the years, they have probably contributed the most to international trade negotiations.
There are usually some trade negotiations going on in the World Trade Organization.
Those frequently bog down, and it takes political judgments and decisions by heads of states to get them going again.
They have very frequently in the past played that role and done so quite effectively.
Unfortunately, they have not done that in recent years.
The fact is that the G8 has really gone down hill over the last 10 years or so.
One reason for that is its growing lack of political legitimacy.
The emerging market economies - China, India, Mexico, Brazil - have become bigger and bigger players...
And none of them are G8 members.
They are not members.
They are invited to so called outreach sessions, but they are not full members, and that's a huge difference.

I think the G8 will never reclaim its legitimacy, and therefore its effectiveness, until it adds members and maybe kicks out some of its current members who are not so relevant, as China and India have now become.

I was looking over the agenda for the summit today and on every day, there is time carved out for a photo opportunity, and there's these social launches and social dinners, is there anything to be said just for these leaders getting together and having that face time?
Does that actually matter?
It does matter for the leaders to have face time.
In fact, one of the great benefits from the summits back in their early days was that there was little by way of photo opportunities and other social occasions.
They really did spend most of their time talking quietly, even without aides, or certainly without very many aides.

And the fact that they got to know each other better did pay off, not so much as the meeting itself, but later on when they needed to get together on a crisis issue or work together towards some broader purpose.

I think part of the deterioration of the G8 performance over the last decade or so has been the increased socialization of the meetings with a greater and greater eye towards the PR effects rather than the substance.
